channel.title: Web Client page tutorial [CSS/HTML]
channel.description: [b][size=18pt]This tutorial is outdated. I'm writing an updated version as we speak. sorry.[/size][/b] Ruby has inspired me to create a web design tutorial. Seeing as this site is all about Private servers, why not make something on that. I'll be writing the code out as I make this tutorial. So it will be some time before it is fully up. NOTE: I will not be using HTML syntax highlighting in the code brackets because I use some html5 elements and these forums only support html4. [b]Section 1: Setting up[/b] So this is the easy step, I think it is easier to create websites with stupidly simple folder structuring. [b]Step (1)[/b] Let's start off by creating a new folder (I will be using my documents). Right click, hover "New", Click Folder. Then Title. Mine will be named "A Website Demo". [img]http://i50.tinypic.com/2e6ae7a.png[/img] [b]Step (2)[/b] Moving on, Within that folder we have just made, lets create some more. I will be creating 2 more folders, "images" (no caps), and "assets". This is really self explanatory. All site images will be held within my "images" folder. html documents will be held in the root folder (what folder we are located in currently), and any other code/files will be located in the 'assets' folder. I simply do this to organize the folders for myself. It is not needed, but a form of organization is recommended. [IMG]http://i.imgur.com/FQYEx.png[/img] [b]Section 2: Writing the HTML[/b] [b]Step (1)[/b] Let's create the shell of our site, shall we not? (I am using Notepad++) Open up your designated text editor, preferably one with html and css syntax highlighting, as that is what we are using. NOTE: Using Dreamweaver is recommended, simply because it is more openly used in the field, and has a lot more tools available to you. But it is not needed. [b][Side Tutorial][/b] If you are using Notepad++ it is best you set up syntax highlighting before saving. As there are over 30 languages it supports. Open Notepad++, click "Language", then hover over "H" for Html (or the letter of your desired language), wait for the menu to expand, and click html. The document should shift slightly, and your good to go. Do The same for your CSS Document later on. [img]http://i46.tinypic.com/fwigx.png[/img] [/Side Tutorial] Now, I start off by writing a small shell of the webpage, again, this isn't needed but it's always good to have it handy. Here is what I enter so you can copy paste (you learn better by typing it yourself): [code] [/code] The code, explained (A tid bit): - In HTML 5, they changed the DOCTYPE tag to be simple, as with a lot of other tags, see W3 - The html element represents the root of a document. (This is really obvious..) - The head element collects the document’s metadata. (Users don't see the head element in use, but instead elements inside of it.) - The title of a document is specified by the TITLE element. Like when you see "Facebook" in the tab on Google Chrome. <body> - The body element represents the body of a document. Or in other terms, the core of your page (There are exceptions, of course). Other element, codes etc. will be explained as we add them. Each element (the words within the angle brackets (Example: <html>)) has an opening tag, and a closing tag. So if you have <html> then you need </html>. Now, there are a few elements that are self-closing. For instance the line break tag, <br />. Note: [b]Most documentation came from the [url=http://www.w3.org/]w3 consortium[/b] Now click "Save" or "Save As..." because it's a new document it will give you the same prompt either way. navigate to the folder you made to contain your website (See Step 1) and save this document. [Extra Information] If you are using Notepad++ like I am, it comes with a built in "Test" feature that can be located in the "Run" menu of the program. This only works after saving. If you are using Dreamweaver, it comes with plenty of built in test/debug features. Such as live view, and live code. It also allows you to split the screen so you see both the code and the live view of the webpage. [/Extra Information] [b]Step (2)[/b] Time to populate the head tag. Remember, users don't see most of what is in this tag. First, lets add a title to the document. All you need to do is add some text (any text) inbetween <title> and . Mine looks like so: [code]My Webclient[/code] Next, we are going to tell the page to use data from a css file. We haven't made the file, but that affects nothing :D [code][/code] What's that code mean? - The link element represents metadata that expresses inter-document relationships href - A URL that provides the destination of the link. rel - A set of tokens that specify the relationship between the document containing the link and the destination indicated by the link. type - The MIME type of the destination of the link. [quote="OldTutorialDownload"][url=http://up.ht/PztsrL]Download the Web client files here![/url][/quote]

item.title: Web Client page tutorial [CSS/HTML]
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:47, topic:455129”]But you’re trying to include styling in your html, which is not semantic. Having bold in your navigation is not semantically correct, run it through a wcag validator and it’ll likely return a similar error.

Yes you can use the bold tag to change the appearance, but it is incorrect, which is what I’m getting at

Oh and, it’s deprecated in xhtml strict 2.0, which will become a standard within the next few years, always good to be future proof.[/quote]
In the new version, the nav bar is going to be style all through css, and bold tags won’t be used what so ever.
I’ve just been taking my sweet ass time writing it

Read full topic

Oh and, it’s deprecated in xhtml strict 2.0, which will become a standard within the next few years, always good to be future proof.

item.title: Web Client page tutorial [CSS/HTML]
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:43, topic:455129”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=558001.msg4193664#msg4193664 date=1357190686]
And you can change the text to bold with CSS, Silent, but you can still use .
It would be rather silly to split 1 paragraph into 3 because you wanted to bold 1 part of it using CSS instead of just using the tag.
[/quote]It’s recommended to use something like for strong emphasis if that’s what you’re aiming for. If you must bold the text using , it’s recommended to give it a class or something in case it needs to be changed later. You also don’t need to split the paragraph into 3 just to bold text, just use an inline (flow) tag with a class.

You still shouldn’t use just to bold text though.[/quote]
Was an example of what a person would do to bold text

Read full topic

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/HTML/Element/b[/quote]

item.title: Web Client page tutorial [CSS/HTML]

item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:40, topic:455129”]Didn’t read it all but tags are deprecated[/quote]The b tags (surprisingly) aren’t deprecated but they should generally be avoided if there’s a better alternative. In this case they weren’t necessary at all like you pointed out.

MDN Web Docs

<b>: The Bring Attention To element

The HTML Bring Attention To element (b)  is used to draw the reader's attention to the element's contents, which are not otherwise granted special importance.

Read full topic

item.title: Web Client page tutorial [CSS/HTML]
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Didn’t read it all but tags are deprecated and the tags in your unordered lists aren’t surrounding any text therefore are unneeded.

Use the css attribute font-weight for the boldness, as it is styling not structure, remember semantics.

Basically change it to this:

<ul class="navigation">
   <li><a href="#">Home</a></li>
   <li class="current"><a href="#">Play Now</a></li>
   <li><a href="#">Forums</a></li>
   <li><a href="#"><em>Download</a></li>
   <li><a href="#">Donate</a></li>
</ul>

Then the CSS would be simply:

ul.navigation li {
   font-weight: 800;
}

Also look into HTML resets, definitely needed, will clean up your CSS a lot.

Read full topic

item.title: Web Client page tutorial [CSS/HTML]
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

Only reason I bumped this is because you referred to it in another topic.

- Refers to w3school's documentation of xhtml and html, it just defines the document. (I copy paste this, as it's not easy to remember no matter what the cost.)
A doctype isn't W3Schools' documentation, it's the W3C's definitions. The W3C and W3Schools are completey different organizations (http://w3fools.com). It's also a better idea to just use to opt-in to using the latest HTML5 features. Most of the page here is valid HTML5 as well.
the tag is another self closing tag. it is used "link" CSS/JavaScript/other documents to your html document. You never physicality see them while you are browsing, but they are everywhere.
The link tag is not used for JavaScript, that's the script tag. Really it's only used to provide CSS and possibly alternative links the page in other languages. http://www.htmldog.com/reference/htmltags/link/
[code=css]div#logo {[/code]
This is more just a personal preference but why would you specify that the element is a div when you're using an ID? IDs are unique, you can't have two elements with the same ID.
[code=css]-moz-transform: translate(10px, 0px); -webkit-transform: translate(10px, 0px);[/code]
Should have really added the normal transform property for future-proofing.
[code=html]
  • Home
    • [/code] [code=html]

    © Sk8rdude461 2012-2013

    [/code]
    I recommend against using the b and center tag as they aren't semantic (they don't describe the document but rather the style, leave that to CSS). The center tag is also deprecated.
    [code=html]Each tag (the things in the <>) has a opening and closing, except for and
    as they are self closing tags.[/code]
    There are more than those two tags that don't require end tags. Also the following code is completely valid HTML (though I don't recommend br at all): [code=html]
    [/code]
    sub-tag "class=" is an identifier, just like ID is. Difference is instead of a "#" in front of the name, it has a "." in CSS.
    You should also have mentioned that you can have multiple elements with the same class but only one element with a unique ID.
    sub-tag "rel=" this specifies what the RELationship is between the linked document and current one.
    They aren't called sub-tags, they're called attributes.
    [code=css] padding-top:0px; padding-bottom:0px; padding-right:30px; padding-left:5px;[/code] [code=css] padding:0 0 0 0px; [/code]
    Didn't really use the shorthand where it was appropriate :P.

    I’d like to mention again, don’t use w3schools.

    Read full topic
